prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We include a broad continuum band. We use other basebands to search for molecular lines. We need relatively broad velocity coverage for outflow tracers such as 12CO and H(30)alpha (~600km/s bandwidth with 0.8km/s resolution). Finer velocity resolution is desired for dense gas / hot core / disk tracers (0.2km/s resolution). For shock tracers SiO and SO2 which may also trace outflows we use (0.8km/s resolution and ~300km/s bandwidth). The spectral set-up has been set to be identical to that of the companion proposal.

We choose a resolution of 0.14". It is the highest resolution without >2km baseline (non-standard mode). We ask for a largest angular scale of 12", the largest recovalbe scale of the most compact 12m array configuration. These will give us a scale range from 280AU to 24000AU at typical 2kpc, i.e. from a scale of massive disk to core scales.

Our sensitivity is 0.08mJy/beam for continuum. Currently best resolution image of dust continuum emission from G35.2 shows extended emission at 5.4 mJy/beam level for a ~0.45" beam at 1mm. That is ~0.24 mJy/beam for a 0.14" beam at 1.3 mm. Therefore we request a rms of 0.08 mJy/beam to detect such extended emission at 3 sigma level.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to characterize the 1.3 mm dust continuum structure of 8 massive protostellar cores over a wide range of scales from ~0.14" to ~12", i.e., ~300AU to 24,000AU at typical distance of 2kpc. The results will be compared against sophisticated radiative transfer models of Core Accretion, which are already constrained by our SOFIA-FORCAST MIR to FIR observations of these same sources. In particular, we will examine to what extent simple, symmetric core models can remain valid when confronted with these new ALMA observations. Our spectral set-up also includes a suite of lines to potentially probe dense gas in core or disk and outflows. In a companion proposal, we seek to observe these same sources with same spectral set-up at resolutions of up to 0.035", and these data would be combined with the observations proposed here to yield images that probe a very large range of scales in massive protostellar cores. Even the results of this project on its own will provide stringent new tests of massive star formation theories. However, in combination with the long baseline companion observations, it will enable truly revolutionary vistas of massive star formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00985.S, The Primordial Multiplicity at Massive Star Birth, Jonathan Tan
